intro: Adeneleuterophora cordidactyla, commonly known as the broad-leaved dandelion, is a flowering plant belonging to the family Asteraceae. It is characterized by its basal rosette of broad, spoon-shaped leaves and a distinctive flower head that develops into a fluffy seed dispersal mechanism. The plant is native to Europe and parts of Asia, and it thrives in a variety of soil types, preferring sunny to partially shaded locations. Its leaves are typically hairy and have a slightly bitter taste, while its flowers are yellow and bloom in the spring. Adeneleuterophora cordidactyla is often found in meadows, gardens, and disturbed soils, and it plays a role in supporting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
